Graphical abstract A series of Zr-containing Mg-Al hydrotalcite-like (HTl) precursors were prepared using co-precipitation method with Zr4+: (Al3+ + Zr4+) from 0 to 0.7. It was demonstrated by X-ray diffraction that the yield of the HTl phase declined on increasing of Zr content. Then, Mg-Al-Zr mixed oxide (CHT-Zr) catalysts were obtained by calcining of the corresponding HTl precursors and they all exhibited mesoporous structure after heat treatment. Based on systemic characterization, it was observed that the amount of Zr additive showed a great effect on the structure and acidic-basic property of CHT-Zr samples. Meanwhile, such CHT-Zr catalysts were effective catalysts for the glycerol carbonate (GLC) synthesis from glycerol and urea. Afterwards, the function of acidic and basic sites in each reaction path identified in this research was elucidated based on the reactant conversion and product selectivity. It proved that the acidic sites were inclined to promote the reaction towards GLC synthesis, while all the paths towards the by-products were significantly catalyzed by the basic sites. However, the catalysts with extra strong acidity did not facilitate the GLC production due to poisoning of surface active sites by urea adsorption. So, a well-balanced acidic-basic property was important to obtain high GLC yield with good selectivity. Among all the catalytic samples, the catalysts with Zr4+: (Al3+ + Zr4+) = 0.3 showed the best catalytic performance with 87.8% yield of GLC. Moreover, different reaction parameters such as reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst amount and vacuum degree were investigated and optimum conditions were established. Additionally, this catalyst could be readily recycled and reused for at least four times without any activation treatment, while still possessing high activity. Keywords Glycerol Glycerol carbonate Urea Hydrotalcite-like Acidic-basic property 1 Introduction As a renewable and clean diesel-engine fuel, biodiesel has received much attention owing to the rising prices of fossil fuels and the worldwide environmental problem associated with global warming [1]. Nevertheless, a large amount of glycerol is formed as unavoidable by-product during the biodiesel production. Generally, about 100 kg of glycerol is manufactured per 1000 kg of biodiesel produced by the transesterification of vegetable oils with methanol. Consequently, the rapidly increasing production of biodiesel induces accumulation of glycerol remarkably [2]. Therefore, conversion of low-grade glycerol to value-added chemicals is highly important and has become a hot research topic. Among different products possible from glycerol, glycerol carbonate (GLC) is one of the most attractive derivatives due to its low toxicity, biodegradability, and high polarity with many potential applications. It has been widely used as a protic solvent, an additive, a component of composite materials, or an electrolyte for lithium batteries. Meanwhile, because of its high reactivity, GLC can also react with alcohols, amines, ketones, isocyanates, and carboxylic acids to produce various valuable products [3,4]. Conventionally, GLC can be synthesized from the reaction of glycerol with phosgene or CO. Nevertheless, the application of these two routines has been restricted by the high toxicity of phosgene and CO [5,6]. Nowadays, the environmental benign GLC synthetic procedures mainly include transesterification of organic carbonates and direct carboxylation of glycerol with CO2. The former suffers from the economical shortcoming using dimethyl carbonate, ethylene or propylene carbonate as raw material owing to that they are commonly prepared through a petrochemical process [7–9]. The latter is considered as a promising method because that CO2 is the major greenhouse gas and also a cheap, nontoxic, abundant C1 feedstock. However, this method is far from industrialization attributed to that CO2 activation requires harsh conditions of temperature and pressure, and the GLC yield is too low to meet satisfaction [10]. Hence, an alternative approach is the glycerolysis of urea, which could be considered as the activated form of CO2. It is well known that approximate 108 tons of urea is synthesized from the reaction of CO2 and ammonia every year worldwide [11]. This aspect coupled with the use of bio-glycerol makes it a cheap, sustainable and non-toxic process. More importantly, the ammonia released during the reaction can be cycled back to urea production, making this method completely atom economical. Thus, the synthesis of GLC based on urea is drawing much more interest in the green chemistry field and numerous catalysts have been reported for this reaction. Homogeneous catalysts such as ZnCl2 [12], LaCl3 [13], ionic liquids [14], and ZMG [diamminediisocyanatozinc (II)] complex [15] showed high catalytic ability. However, they were limited by inconvenient catalyst recovery. Up to now, different kinds of heterogeneous catalysts including La2O3 [16], Sn-W mixed oxide [17], γ-zirconium phosphate [18], polymer-supported metal containing ionic liquid catalyst [19], gypsum and gold based catalyst [20,21] have been respectively studied for this reaction, and many promising results were achieved. Compared to them, ZnO was highly active towards the reaction, yielding 85.97% of GLC [22]. Unfortunately, it was a precursor of homogeneous catalyst for the GLC production [23]. In order to overcome this disadvantage, N. Lingaiah et al. prepared zinc exchanged heteropoly tungstate (ZnxTPA) catalyst, but the glycerol conversion was lower than 70% [24]. S.E. Kondawar et al. reported that zinc loaded MCM-41 catalyst could improve the GLC synthesis. However, the glycerol conversion was only about 75% [25]. Zn-HY zeolite was considered to be a highly active solid catalyst for the GLC synthesis, but a large amount of catalyst (15 wt%) was needed [26]. At the same time, zinc-based mixed oxides including Zn-Co [27], Zn-Al, Zn-Li-Al and Zn-Mg-Al [28] mixed oxide catalysts were prepared to catalyze GLC production. Nevertheless, Sun et al. reported that their active ZnO phase was prone to generating homogeneous coordinates Zn(NCO)2(NH3)2 and dissolved into the reaction medium [28]. Consequently, it was evident that the homogeneous catalytic route was dominant in the reaction of glycerol and urea over these catalytic materials. Therefore, it is still a challenging task to develop efficient and stable heterogeneous catalysts that are prepared via a simple and repeatable way for the synthesis of GLC from glycerol and urea. In addition to the catalyst composition, the property of precursor has a great effect on the structure and catalytic performance of catalyst. Typically, mixed oxides could be acquired by the calcination of hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTlcs). Usually, they can be determined as: [M2+ 1− x M3+ x (OH)2] x +(A n −) x / n ·mH2O, where part of divalent cations represented as M2+ could be replaced isomorphously by trivalent cations described as M3+, giving positively charged layers [29]. These HTlcs have been applied as precursors of catalysts for many reactions because that the as-obtained mixed oxides have high specific surface and stability against sintering after controlled thermal decomposition of HTlcs [30–33]. More importantly, the properties of the mixed oxides acquired after thermal treatment could be tuned through the adjustment of cationic composition of HTlcs. So, HTlcs with a wide variety of mono- to tetravalent cations have been synthesized with increasing interest. In view of this, the incorporation of tetravalent cations, which could considerably modify the layer charge, was an attractive method for the formation of remarkable acidic-basic properties [32,34–36]. It has been demonstrated that Zr-containing hydrotalcite-derived mixed oxides are effective catalysts for transesterification in biodiesel production [37]. Nevertheless, the effect of Zr doping on the acidic-basic properties of calcined HTlcs and their catalytic performance for the GLC synthesis have been not extensively investigated. Therefore, in this work, we prepared a series of Mg-Al-Zr mixed oxide catalysts derived from the corresponding Mg-Al-Zr HTlcs, which were synthesized with Zr4+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) atomic ratios varied from 0 to 0.7. All the mixed oxides and their hydrotalcite-like (HTl) precursors were characterized using various techniques such as XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, TG-DSC, SEM, TEM, ICP, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD. Then, the reaction system that affected the GLC yield was elucidated and every reaction path was individually studied over these catalysts in detail. The relationship between the conversion of reactants, the selectivity and yield of products, and the acidic-basic properties was systemically investigated to clarify the role of acidic-basic sites for the synthesis of GLC. Moreover, the optimization of reaction conditions was attempted and the GLC yield could reach 87.8% over the best catalytic-performance catalyst. Finally, based on catalyst characterization and reusability test, a stable heterogeneous catalyst system with high activity was successfully developed for the GLC synthesis from urea and glycerol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Mg-Al-Zr hydrotalcite-like compounds (Mg2+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) = 3:1) were obtained using co-precipitation method followed by controlled hydrothermal treatment [32]. The Mg2+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) atomic ratio in mother solution maintained at 3:1, while the Zr4+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) atomic ratio was varied from 0 to 0.7. Typically, two 100 mL aqueous solution, a solution containing Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, and a mixed solution of NaOH and Na2CO3 as the precipitating agent, were added dropwise to 100 mL deionized water with vigorous stirring at room temperature. During this procedure, the pH value was kept close to 10.0 by addition of appropriate amount of NaOH solution. The resulting gel-like slurry was put into autoclave and hydrothermally treated at 100 °C for 20 h. After cooling to room temperature, the slurry was filtrated and washed with deionized water until neutral pH value was reached. Afterwards, the filter cakes were dried at 80 °C overnight to obtain the HTlcs samples. Finally, the mixed oxide catalysts were acquired by thermal decomposition of the resulting HTl precursors in an oven at 500 °C for 6 h in N2 atmosphere. The synthesized HTlcs and corresponding mixed oxide were described as HT-xZr and CHT-xZr, respectively, where x/10 was the Zr4+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) atomic ratio in the initial mother solution. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) were obtained on Rigaku Miniflex diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation in a 2θ range of 5–80°. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were acquired at liquid nitrogen temperature, −196 °C on a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 instrument (Norcross, GA), using static adsorption procedures. All the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 6 h before measurement. The BET method and BJH were applied to calculate specific surface area and the pore size distribution, respectively. Thermal decomposition of the as-prepared hydrotalcite-like samples were investigated using thermogravimetric (TG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) method on a NETZSCH STA-409 thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C /min from room temperature to 700 °C. The atmosphere for the TG analysis was N2 at 30 mL/min. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) image of samples was taken on a Hitachi S4800 detector with an accelerating voltage of 20.00 kV. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments were performed on an FEI Tecnai F20 transmission electron microscope with a field emission gun operating at 200 kV. The elemental chemical analysis of samples was measured by an inductively coupled plasma-optical (ICP) emission spectroscopy (PerkinElmer ICP OPTIMA-3000). The acidity and basisity of catalysts were determined by temperature programmed desorption (TPD) measurement employing ammonia and carbon dioxide as the probe molecule, respectively. The samples (0.1 g, 40–60 mesh) were taken in a quartz reactor bed and pretreated in Ar flow at 500 °C for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, they were saturated with the probe molecule stream (30 mL min−1) using a six-way valve for 3 h and were subsequently flushed with Ar flow (40 mL min−1) to remove physical adsorbed molecules. Then, the TPD experiments were started from 30 to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under Ar flow (40 mL min−1). During this procedure, the effluent was detected by an AMETEK mass spectrometer, and their peak area was quantitatively calibrated by injecting of pure NH3 and CO2 pulses preliminarily, respectively. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The catalytic performances of catalysts towards the reaction of glycerol and urea were evaluated in a 100 mL one-neck round bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a rotary evaporator. Typically, after 50 mmol glycerol, 50 mmol urea and 0.2 g freshly prepared catalysts placed in the reactor, the pressure was reduced to 10 kPa using an aspirator to remove ammonia. And then, the reaction mixture was heated to 140 °C in an oil bath and maintained at this temperature for 3 h under stirring. After reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and the product mixtures were weighted. Subsequently, the solid catalyst was separated by centrifugation and the liquid products were diluted by ethanol and analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Aglient-6820) with a SE-54 capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The products were identified by a GC–MS (Agilent 7890-700B) with HP-5MS capillary column (30 m). As to the GLC decomposition reaction, a mixture of the GLC (50 mmol) and 0.2 g catalyst was charged into the reactor, and the reaction was conducted at 140 °C for 3 h under stirring. After the reactor was cooled to room temperature, the product mixture was weighed, separated by centrifugation and determined on GC and GC–MS. The intra-cyclization of 2,3-dihydroxypropyl carbamate (2-HPC) in glycerol was also carried out in this research, and the reaction procedure was identical to that of reaction between urea and glycerol. The starting amount of 2-HPC, glycerol and catalyst were 50 mmol, 50 mmol and 0.2 g, respectively, and the liquid products were quantified on GC. 3 Resuls and discussion 3.1 Textural and structure properties of the prepared materials Fig. 1 (a) demonstrates XRD patterns of as-prepared HT-Zr precursors. Apparently, all the samples showed the characteristic diffraction patterns of the pure hydrotalcite [29]. However, because that Zr4+ (0.072 nm) had a larger ionic radius in comparison with that of Al3+ (0.053 nm), substituent of Al3+ by Zr4+ would lead to large distortions in the HTl layers [38]. As a result, the sharpness and intensities of peaks at 2θ of 11.2° and 22.9°, which were related to the crystallinity of materials, decreased with increasing Zr content. According to previous literatures, high Al content was demonstrated to benefit the generation of HTl phase [36,39]. In the present case, the starting Mg2+:(Al3++Zr4+) atomic ratio was kept 3:1 when the precursors were synthesized. Therefore, the Al content decreased with the increase of x, resulting in decrease of HTl phase and co-formation of amorphous phase (hydroxides and hydroxyl carbonates) for HT-7Zr sample [40]. In addition, compared to pure Mg-Al hydrotalcite, the two peaks at (110) and (113) planes presented a small shift from higher to lower 2θ value with increase of Zr content, indicating that incorporation of Zr could affect the deformation of ordered structure of precursors [37]. Two important crystallographic parameters a (2d 110) and c (3d 003), which were calculated on the basis of XRD patterns, are listed in Table 1 . The parameter a, which was at range of 3.061–3.081 Å, representing the average cation-cation distance, followed Vegard’s rule for the solid solutions. Meanwhile, the value of parameter c (23.598–24.962 Å) was consistent with the interaction of CO3 2− ion [29,36]. This implied that Zr4+ could be incorporated into the HTl layers [40]. The XRD patterns of samples after treated at 500 °C are shown in Fig. 1(b). Obviously, no characteristic reflection assigned to HTlcs was detected, demonstrating that the HTl structure was destroyed completely. CHT-0Zr and CHT-1Zr materials exhibited three diffraction peaks at 2θ of 35.6°, 43.2° and 62.5°, which could be assigned to periclase MgO-like structure (PDF No. 45-946). With respect to CHT-3Zr, CHT-5Zr and CHT-7Zr samples, the peak at 35.6° disappeared, and only a broad diffraction peak corresponding to tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2, PDF No. 49-1642) appeared at 30.8°. In addition, no diffraction peak due to Al2O3 was observed for all the samples. This phenomenon implied that Al2O3 might exist in an amorphous state [36]. More important, the lattice parameters obtained at the 2θ of 43.2° of this-like MgO were all less than that of pure MgO (4.21 Å) (see Table 2 ) [41]. This proved that some Al and Zr cations were incorporated into MgO lattice to generate a solid solution, which might be favorable to improve the catalyst stability during reaction. The TG-DTG-DSC curves of HT-Zr precursors are demonstrated in Fig. S1 (see Supporting information). All materials exhibited an endothermic peak around 200 °C with a shoulder peak at about 80 °C, which were caused by elimination of water molecules. A single endothermic peak could be found at around 400 °C, which was attributed to the collapse of the layered structure [29,36,37]. Furthermore, with the addition of Zr, the strength of hydrogen bonds between water molecules and interlayer anions would decline, leading to the decrease of electrostatic interaction between the layers and anions [36,40,42]. Therefore, the decomposition peak position for the Zr-containing samples gradually shifted to lower temperature with increase of x. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution of CHT-Zr catalysts are shown in Fig. S2 (see Supporting information). Noticeably, all the catalysts displayed typical IV isotherms with clear hysteresis loops at higher pressure, revealing that mesoporous structures were formed after calcination [43,44]. The nitrogen adsorption data of the catalysts are listed in Table 2. Generally, a high Al2O3 content in catalyst facilitated increase of BET surface area [45,46]. Simultaneously, it was found that Al content in HTl precursors could enhance CO3 2− contents in the interlayer, favoring generation of more open structure after calcination [47]. Here, as the increase of Zr:Al atomic ratio, the Al content in catalysts decreased, thus, their BET surface area decreased with increasing of x. In addition, the formation of ZrO2 phase might also account for the low surface area of CHT-5Zr and CHT-7Zr samples (see Fig. 1(b)). The morphologies of the HT-Zr precursors are shown in Fig. S3 (see Supporting information). For Zr-free sample, it had a relatively uniform hexagonal platelet-shaped structure [35]. Upon introduction of Zr, this image transformed to flower-like plates with appearance of many fragments. The crystals of the mixed oxide catalysts also kept the similar morphology to that of the precursors, but some particles were destroyed (see Supporting information, Fig. S4). With the increasing of Zr content, some round crystals were detected. Especially, CHT-7Zr catalytic material exhibited almost circular and homogeneous particles. The TEM images for HT-Zr precursors are illustrated in Fig. S5 (see Supporting information). It could be found that all the samples consisted of platelet-like crystals, which was in agreement of the results of SEM measurement. Meanwhile, the particles of CHT-Zr catalysts still mantained the similar morphology to that of HT-Zr samples (see Supporting information, S6). However, CHT-7Zr catalytic material exhibited mainly spherically shaped particles, and minor amounts of plate-like crystals could be observed. 3.2 The surface acidity-basicity properties of mixed oxides catalysts NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD techniques were carried out to measure the strength and the total amount of acidic and basic sites of the mixed oxides, respectively. The acidic and basic species could be determined by the desorption temperature at which peaks appeared and higher desorption temperature represented stronger strength of acidic or basic sites. Moreover, the amount of desorbed NH3 and CO2, which was reflected by the peak area, were respectively proportional to the amount of acidic and basic sites [48]. The NH3-TPD curves of CHT-Zr catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2 (a). One can see that all the profiles contained three Gaussian peaks, which could be assigned to weakly (30–200 °C), moderately (200–400 °C) and strongly acidic sites (>400 °C), respectively [49]. Both the moderately and strongly acidic sites moved to lower temperature as the increasing of Zr content, revealing that introduction of Zr into Mg-Al mixed oxides gave rise to decrease of strength of moderately and strongly acidic sites. Meanwhile, the acidity of all samples is summarized in Table 2. It was known that ZrO2 was less acidic than Al2O3 [50]. Therefore, more acidic sites formed on the surface of Zr-free sample and it decreased with rise of Zr content. The total number of acidic sites of CHT-0Zr possessed about twice that of the CHT-7Zr sample. Thus, compared to Al, Zr exhibited negative effect on the acidic property of catalysts. Furthermore, above-mentioned discussion acknowledged that the specific surface area increased as the increasing of the Al content. This was also beneficial for exposing more acidic sites for CHT-0Zr catalyst. Fig. 2(b) displays the CO2-TPD curves of the CHT-Zr samples. Similar to that of NH3-TPD, all the profiles could be split into three Gussian peaks. The weakly basic sites (30–200 °C) were corresponding to OH− groups, moderately basic sites (200–400 °C) were assigned to metal-oxygen pairs (including Mg-O, Al-O and Zr-O), and strongly basic sites (>400 °C) were derived from low-coordination oxygen atoms [35,36,44]. Table 2 gives the amounts of basic sites of the catalysts. It could be found that the basiciy of Zr-containing catalysts is more than that of the Zr-free sample. More important, their total amount of basic sites increased with rise of Zr content. This might be due to the fact that the influence of Zr4+ on the total basic density might be double-faced. On the one hand, the incorporation of Zr gave rise to decrease of surface area, causing the decrease of exposed basic sites. On the other hand, higher content of Zr4+ introduction into layers, higher net electronic charge of the layers in Zr-modified catalysts, leading to a greater number of low-coordination oxygen atoms, and O2− sites in the vicinity of Zr4+ could be stronger anionic sites than those in the vicinity of Al3+ [50,51]. At the same time, the insertion of Zr could increase the amount of Zr-O pairs, which was greatly favorable for the enhancement of moderately basicity. Furthermore, for these catalysts, more t-ZrO2 phase was available with higher Zr additive amount, which would lead to the strongly absorbed CO2 over their surface [36,52]. This also could improve their surface basicity. Clearly, the positive influence of Zr on basic property surpassed its negative effect in this work. As a consequence, CHT-7Zr sample exhibited the largest amounts of basic sites, whereas the lowest basicity existed on the surface of CHT-0Zr catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic performance of catalysts 3.3.1 Reaction system of glycerol and urea to produce GLC In order to clarify the reaction pathways of urea transesterification with glycerol, the chemical compositions of reaction mixture were determined using GC–MS. The possible reaction products detected were presented and numbered in Scheme 1 . During the reaction, the intermediate 2-HPC (3) was firstly synthesized from glycerol and urea. Subsequently, the main product GLC (4) was obtained via intra-cyclization of 2-HPC, releasing an ammonia molecule. In addition to the major products and paths above-mentioned, there were two other by-products found. The first one was 4-(hydroxymethyl) oxazolidin-2-one (4-OX, 5), which was formed via dehydration of 2-HPC (Box B in Scheme 1). The other by-product detected was glycidol (GD, 6), generated by decarbonylation of GLC with release of a CO2 molecule (Box C in Scheme 1). In addition, Hammond and his co-workers reported that (2-oxo-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl) methyl carbamate could be generated from the reaction of GLC and surplus urea [53]. However, only trace amount of it was detected in the present case. So, this product and reaction path were not taken into account. In order to found out the function of acidic and basic sites of catalysts, the reaction paths towards GLC, and 4-OX from 2-HC as well as GD from GLC in Scheme 1 were separately studied, respectively in the following work. 3.3.2 Catalytic performance for the reaction of glycerol and urea Catalysts performance was studied for the reaction between glycerol and urea, and the results are shown in Table 3 . Apparently, the reaction could take place to some extent and the conversion of glycerol was about 32.6% without catalysts. However, GLC yield was only 26.6%. Simultaneously, it should be noted that a considerable selectivity to 2-HPC (17.7%), as the intermediate of GLC, was obtained along with minor production of 4-OX and GD. When CHT-0Zr sample was used as the catalyst, the GLC yield could be 39.9%. More important, it gave the highest GLC selectivity (97.6%) among all the catalysts. Under the same reaction condition, the GLC yield and product selectivity differed markedly among these Zr-containing catalytic materials, demonstrating that the amount of Zr could significantly affect their catalytic performance. Additionally, CHT-0.1Zr could give 94.1% GLC selectivity, which was only a bit lower than that of CHT-0Zr. More important, an excellent catalytic performance in terms of GLC yield was achieved over CHT-0.3Zr, giving 87.8% yield of GLC. Compared to CHT-0.5Zr and CHT-0.7Zr samples, this catalyst could effectively prevented the production of 4-OX (3.4% selectivity), and the secondary reaction product GD (3.7% selectivity). Further rise of Zr content in catalytic materials resulted in decrease of GLC selectivity enormously. This was more evident for CHT-0.7Zr material. Despite its glycerol conversion was higher than that of CHT-0.1Zr, its GLC selectivity was the lowest (64.3%) in the present work. On the contrary, the selectivity for undesired side products was very high, reaching even 12.3% and 17.5% towards 4-OX and GD, respectively. As a consequence, the GLC yield over this sample was only 43.6%. Therefore, it could be concluded that incorporation of Zr into Mg-Al mixed oxide could promote GLC yield, but the selectivity of GLC gradually decreased as increase of Zr content. To obtain the influence of acidic-basic property of the catalysts on the overall reaction of urea and glycerol, we displayed the urea conversion at 1 h when the reaction was at the beginning in Fig. 3 (a). After extensive screening, the sequence of urea conversion appeared to show a clear trend with that of catalyst acidity. Clearly, urea conversion first increased as surface acidity of catalyst increased, and a maximum of 52.8% was observed for CHT-0.3Zr material. Then, a gradual decrease was found when the amount of acidic sites further increased. That was to say, the reactivity of catalysts appeared to parallel with their total acidity, but too substantial acidic sites would suppress urea activation. Urea was considered as a weakly basic molecule and a donor of electron pairs [54]. So, the carbonyl group of urea would be activated on the acidic sites of mixed oxide catalysts via coordination of O and N atoms to metal cations. At the same time, for mixed oxides, the electrophilicity of metal cation depended on their surface acidity [55], and more acidic sites implied stronger electrophilicity of metal cation, undoubtedly leading to stronger interaction between urea and catalysts. Consequently, this indicated that urea conversion would increase as the increase of acidity of catalyst. However, urea could interact with and absorb strongly on the acidic sites of catalysts if excessive acidic sites were available, which resulted in poisoning of surface catalytic sites for further reaction. Similar results was also illustrated in previous reports, in which the reaction of diols and urea was prevented significantly over acidic sites owing to generation of stable coordination of O and N atoms of urea to metal cations with extra-strong electrophilicity [55,56]. 3.3.3 GLC decomposition into GD As mentioned earlier, the desired target product GLC could decompose into GD with loss of CO2 in the secondary reaction. This reaction should be avoided, thus, in order to know the relationship of GLC conversion between the acidity and basicity of the catalysts. This reaction path was individually studied and the analysis of residual liquid product provided the possibility to determine the activity of catalysts for this reaction. In the course of careful examination, one could clearly observe that the order of GLC conversion was in accordance with that of the total number basic sites of samples (see Fig. 3(b)). The catalysts such as CHT-0Zr and CHT-0.1Zr with small number of basic sites exhibited low GLC conversion, whereas strongly basic material, e.g. CHT-0.7Zr, gave high GLC conversion. This displayed that the activity of catalysts for GLC decomposition might originate from their basic sites. Similar results had been reported by others. Parameswaram et al. proposed that the decarbonylation of GLC was facilitated by the basicity of the catalyst [57]. Very recently, we ascertained that the catalytic ability of catalysts for the GLC decomposition was owing to the presence of strong basic sites [58]. Thus, it was probable that the undesired side reaction of GLC decomposition could be inhibited by reducing the number of basic sites of catalysts. 3.3.4 Intra-cyclization of 2-HPC in glycerol In the process of glycerolysis of urea, it was generally accepted that the intermediate 2-HPC could be formed by the reaction of urea and glycerol with high yield even without catalysts. However, intra-cyclization of 2-HPC to GLC was usually considered to be the rate-control step and high yield of GLC was achieved only in the presence of catalysts [17,19,21,22,27]. Thereby, the intra-cyclization of 2-HPC in glycerol was investigated to elucidate the function of acidic and basic sites for the synthesis of GLC without urea. As displayed in Scheme 1, GLC and all other by-products could be generated via the reaction of 2-HPC and glycerol. Because that the GLC decarbonylation into GD was studied above-mentioned, here, 2-HPC conversion, GLC and 4-OX selectivity were used to estimate the effect of the role of acidic and basic sites of catalysts. Through careful search and investigation, an obvious relationship was established between 2-HPC conversion and the total amount of basic sites for these catalysts (see Fig. 3(c)). When the catalyst possessed more basic density, higher 2-HPC conversion was achieved. In other words, more basic sample showed better reactivity for the intra-cyclization of 2-HPC towards GLC. On the contrary, mixed oxides with higher acidity resulted in more GLC selective, which could be found in Fig. 3(d). For instance, CHT-0Zr sample, which possessed the highest amount of acidic sites, gave about 94% selectivity towards GLC. So, it was likely that the acidic property was important to shift the reaction from 2-HPC to the GLC path but not to 4-OX path. Hence, the materials with lower acidity, i.e. more basic samples, exhibited unsatisfied GLC selectivity, driving the reaction towards the 4-OX formation. The above experimental results could be explained as follows: first, the 2-HPC molecule was absorbed on the surface of mixed oxides via coordination of nitrogen atom with the cationic surface metal (Mg, Al or Zr) atoms of the catalyst. Consequently, the electrons of the CN bond would be redistributed, then, the proton moved to the carbon atom with the presence of a carbocation and a nitrogen anion (see Scheme 2 (a)). Meanwhile, the neighboring hydroxyl group of 2-HPC was activated through the abstraction of H δ+ by the basic sites of catalysts, resulting in formation a strong nucleophilic group. Subsequently, the oxygen in hydroxyl attacked the carbon in neighboring carbonyl group, leading to the formation of the tetrahedron transition complex. Then, a positive ion group of NH3 was produced as the consequence of interaction between NH2 and proton hydrogen. Finally, GLC was produced by releasing of NH3. It was reasonable that the more basicity could give more negative charge of O δ − in hydroxyl, causing the lower free energy for intra-cyclization of 2-HPC to GLC. So, the conversion of 2-HPC was increased with rise of the catalyst basicity. This was in line with the results in the previous work, in which Lewis-basic centres were found to be crucial for Mg-Al mixed oxide catalysts to obtain high GC yield [59]. However, the catalyst with too substantial basic sites could induce inferior GLC selectivity. The reason might be as follows: similar to hydroxyl group, the NH2 group in 2-HPC could be also activated by the extra-strong basic sites on surface of catalyst with appearance of the nitrogen atom with unshared electron-pair, accompanying release of H δ+ (see Scheme 2(b)). Meanwhile, the electrons of CO group would be redistributed with appearance of a carbocation neighboring the activated hydroxyl group. And then, the negative ion group of NH would attack this positive anion of carbon atom to generate a new CN bound. In the end, the side product 4-OX was synthesized with expulsion of a H2O molecule. Thereby, the catalyst with too many basic densities could promote the dehydration of GLC. This hypothesis was further confirmed by the results shown in Fig. 3(e). Clearly, the 4-OX selectivity differed drastically among the CHT-Zr catalysts. More important, it was worth noting that CHT-0Zr catalyst, which possessed the lowest number of basic sites, only brought out 3.7% selectivity of 4-OX. For Zr-incorporated samples, the 4-OX selectivity increased as increasing of Zr content. Especially, the 4-OX selectivity obtained on the CHT-7Zr (27.6%) could be about seven times of that over pure Mg-Al mixed oxide. Considering the total amount of basic sites increased with the rise of x from 0 to 0.7, so, it proved that the dehydration of 4-HPC could be catalyzed on the surface basic sites of catalytic materials. Simultaneously, Bhanage et al. suggested that catalysts including CaO and La2O3 with strong basic property showed high reactivity for dehydration of 2-hydroxyethyl carbamate to produce 2-oxazolidone [60]. This was consistent with the finding of this investigation. Thereby, the by-reaction of dehydration of 2-HPC might be depressed by reducing the amount of basic sites of catalysts. 3.3.5 The function of acidic and basic sites for the carbonylation of glycerol by urea Based on the experimental results and discussion above-mentioned, it was found that the amount of Zr in the catalysts presented enormous effect on the acidic-basic properties of Zr-incorporated Mg-Al mixed oxides, and consequently affected their reactivity, reaction path and GLC yield. So, the key to achieve high GLC yield with good selectivity was to tune the acidic-basic properties of catalysts. Based on the results and discussion above-mentioned, it was expected that an appropriate-balanced acidic and basic property was the decisive factor to obtain high GLC yield when the reaction was conducted from urea and glycerol. Indeed, this conclusion was confirmed by the result displayed in Fig. 3(f). One can see that CHT-0.3Zr give the highest GLC yield due to its balanced A/B value, while lower yield of GLC was obtained over extra strong acidic (CHT-0Zr) or basic (CHT-7Zr) samples. Compared to them, the lower basiciy of CHT-3Zr was crucial for guiding the reaction more selective. At the same time, urea could be activated on its weak acidic sites without being poisoned, which might happen when CHT-0Zr and CHT-1Zr were used as catalyst. The importance of balance acidic-basic properties of catalysts in this or analogue reaction has been also reported by others. Climent et al. discovered that high reactivity and selectivity of Zn-Al mixed oxide for urea glycerolysis was owing to its well-balanced acidic-basic properties [8]. Very recently, D. Fakhrnasova and his co-workers found that Zn-Fe mixed oxides could promote urea transesterification with ethylene glycol efficiently because of its unique acid-base property [56]. Similar experimental results were also disclosed by Ball et al. and they reported that an adequate combination of a weak Lewis acid and a Lewis base was responsible for high activity of catalysts when they catalyzed the reaction of primary and secondary alcohols with urea [61]. Thus, on the basis of experimental results and discussion afore-mentioned, it was reasonable to conclude that although the target product GLC could be synthesized over acidic sites with high selectivity, the activity of catalysts with too-strong acidic sites would be inhibited due to its active site poisoning by urea absorption for the reaction of urea and glycerol. With the respect to the basic sites, they could promote the production of undesired product, resulting in decrease of GLC selectivity severely. In view of these facts, it can be concluded that the key for catalyst giving high GLC yield with good selectivity is to possess well-balanced amounts of acidic and basic sites. 3.4 Optimization of reaction conditions Apart from the acidic-basic property, the reaction parameters could also affect the GLC synthesis markedly. Therefore, the influence of experimental factors such as reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst amount, and vacuum degree were optimized using CHT-3Zr sample as the model catalyst. 3.4.1 Influence of reaction temperature A typical profile of effect of reaction temperature is displayed in Fig. 4 (a). Obviously, glycerol conversion was very low when the temperature was below 120 °C. Then, it rose sharply up to 96.7% as the reaction temperature reached 140 °C, indicating that reaction temperature showed an enormous effect on the GLC synthesis. Meanwhile, the GLC selectivity and yield also increased to 90.8% and 87.8%, respectively. Nevertheless, further increase of temperature hardly gave rise to apparently increase of glycerol conversion, but resulted in a notable decrease of GLC selectivity. This was because that higher temperature could also aggravate undesired reactions such as dehydration of 2-HPC and decarbonylation of GLC. Consequently, the GLC yield decreased significantly. Thereby, the suitable reaction temperature should be selected as 140 °C. 3.4.2 Influence of reaction time Fig. 4(b) gives the influence of reaction time in the range of 1–5 h. At beginning, the glycerol conversion and GLC selectivity increased as the increase of reaction time, and the GLC yield reached the maximum value of 87.8% at 3 h. The glycerol conversion was observed to increase continuously as the reaction further extension to 5 h, but the GLC yield decreased to 77.9% with 78.5% selectivity attributed to the formation of by-products. Thus, the optimal reaction time should be 3 h. 3.4.3 Influence of catalyst amount The influence of catalyst amount was also studied (see Fig. 4(c)). One can see that the glycerol conversion always enhance with the increase of catalyst amount. However, the GLC selectivity and yield reached their peak values at 0.2 g, and then decreased with further increase of catalyst amount. So, the appropriate catalyst amount was chosen as 0.2 g in this case. 3.4.4 Influence of vacuum degree In addition, the influence of vacuum degree on the GLC synthesis is illustrated in Fig. 4 (d). As expected, the glycerol conversion consistently increased as the vacuum degree increased from 50 kPa to 10 kPa. The reason was that a low pressure was favorable for the removal of the ammonia generated during the reaction, thus pushing the reaction of urea and glycerol towards the GLC production [19]. Both the GLC selectivity and yield presented the similar trend during this process. Further increasing vacuum degree led to slightly decrease of GLC selectivity, implying that the consumption of GLC in further reaction surpassed the production of GLC. Thereby, the preferable vacuum degree was 10 kPa in this research. 3.5 Catalyst stability In view of standpoint of industrial production, not only high initial reactivity, but also high stability of catalyst was required. Therefore, it was desirable to investigate the reusability and stability of CHT-3Zr catalyst which showed the best catalytic performance. The CHT-3Zr material after each reaction was recovered by centrifuge, washed with ethanol with three times, dried at 100 °C and then reused for the next run. Their catalytic performances are shown in Fig. 5 . To our delight, the catalyst exhibited good recyclability with minimal decrease in the activity after used four times. Importantly, the GLC selectivity remained almost constant in each recycle. Furthermore, to study the structure change of the catalyst, the recovered CHT-3Zr catalyst (CHT-3Zr-fourth) was measured using XRD, SEM and N2 adsorption-desorption techniques. Similar to fresh catalyst, it still maintained the sheet-like morphology (see Fig. S4). Simultaneously, XRD pattern of CHT-3Zr-fourth sample was not found to any obvious change compare to that of fresh one (see Fig.1 (b)). Additionally, the BET surface of CHT-3Zr-fourth catalyst was 114 m2 g−1, which was only 3 m2 g−1 lower than that of the fresh catalyst. Hence, both the results of catalytic test and characterization indicated that CHT-3Zr catalyst possessed higher stability than previously explored zinc-containing catalysts towards this reaction. 3.6 Comparison of CHT-3Zr catalyst with other reported representative solid catalyst Catalytic performance of CHT-3Zr catalyst was compared with other solid catalysts reported previously (see Table 4 ). Obviously, basic oxide MgO exhibited much lower activity than that of CHT-3Zr catalyst [8], mainly due to the presence only strong basic sites on their surface. Although gold supported catalysts had high conversion, the GLC yield was very low with high catalyst cost [53]. Sn-W mixed oxide presented higher activity, but still far from satisfactory [17]. As to Sn-β zeolite, its major shortcoming was that the GLC yield was only 26%. Simultaneously, it required a long time for achieving a high glycerol conversion [8]. Among the acidic samples, zirconium phosphate could give about 80% glycerol conversion with almost 100% GLC selectivity. Nevertheless, its recyclability was poor and the activity became decline upon reuse [18]. Zinc-based catalysts such as ZnO [22], Zn-Co [27] and Zn-Al [28] mixed oxides were selected as efficient catalysts towards this reaction. However, it was considered that these catalysts might suffer from easy leaching [23]. In case of zinc supported catalysts such as Zn1TPA [24] and Zn-MCM-41 [25], their major problem might also be the easy leaching active component. Compared to all the catalysts above-mentioned, the present CHT-3Zr catalyst could improve this reaction efficiently with about 87.8% glycerol conversion and with near 91% selectivity towards GLC. Importantly, this catalyst was reusable, and its preparation process was simple and repeatable. Thereby, it could be concluded that the CHT-3Zr material is an active, stable and practical catalyst for GLC synthesis by reaction of glycerol and urea. 4 Conclusion A series of Mg-Al-Zr catalysts derived from Zr-incorporated Mg-Al hydrotalciet-like precursors with Zr4+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) from 0 to 0.7 were successfully prepared via a simple and repeatable co-precipitation method. During the calcination process, mesoporous structure was formed in all these mixed oxides. More importantly, the Zr content could affect significantly the acidic-basic property and catalytic performance of the Mg-Al-Zr catalysts for the GLC synthesis from glycerol and urea. The roles of acidic and basic sites for each reaction path were found out based on the investigation of the correlations between catalytic performances and acidic-basic properties of the catalysts. Some useful conclusions might be concluded as follows: 1) The pure and crystalline Mg-Al-Zr hydrotalcite-like compounds could be synthesized by the substituent of Al3+ with Zr4+. However, it was demonstrated that the yields of hydrotalcite-like phase declined on the increasing of Zr content. 2) The structural, textual and acidic-basic properties of Zr-containing Mg-Al mixed oxides strongly depended on the amount of Zr additive. The results displayed that the total amount of acidic sites increased with the rise of Zr content, while the opposite trend for the total number of basic sites was observed for present Zr-modified Mg-Al mixed oxides. As a result, there existed a well-balanced proportion of surface acidic and basic sites when Zr4+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) atomic ratio was 0.3. 3) Based on the catalytic results of all samples in the reaction of glycerol and urea, and in every comprising reaction pathway indentified in present research, it was disclosed that the target product GLC could be generated selectively over acidic sites. Unfortunately, the activity of catalytic materials would be prevented on the catalysts that had too many acidic sites. This was because that a strong interaction occurred between urea and acidic sites, resulting in poisoning of active sites for further reaction. The undesired reactions such as decarbonylation and 2-HPC dehydration were catalyzed drastically by basic sites and the GLC selectivity decreased as increasing of concentration of basic sites. Consequently, the catalysts with well-balanced number of acidic and basic sites were beneficial for obtaining high GLC yield with high selectivity. 4) Among all the catalysts, Mg-Al-Zr mixed oxide with Zr4+:(Al3+ + Zr4+) = 0.3 presented the best overall performance towards the GLC synthesis. A higher GLC yield of 87.8% with excellent 90.8% selectivity was achieved under the optimal reaction conditions using CHT-3Zr catalyst. In addition, this catalyst was proved to be reusable for several times without any pre-treatment and maintained consistent activity. Furthermore, it showed high stability on the basis of characteristic results of SEM, XRD and N2 adsorption-desorption techniques. Thus, this work has provided an active, stable and practical catalyst system for the economical and green synthesis of GLC from glycerol and urea. coredata.dc:description: A series of Zr-containing Mg-Al hydrotalcite-like (HTl) precursors were prepared using co-precipitation method with Zr4+: (Al3+ + Zr4+) from 0 to 0.7. It was demonstrated by X-ray diffraction that the yield of the HTl phase declined on increasing of Zr content. Then, Mg-Al-Zr mixed oxide (CHT-Zr) catalysts were obtained by calcining of the corresponding HTl precursors and they all exhibited mesoporous structure after heat treatment. Based on systemic characterization, it was observed that the amount of Zr additive showed a great effect on the structure and acidic-basic property of CHT-Zr samples. Meanwhile, such CHT-Zr catalysts were effective catalysts for the glycerol carbonate (GLC) synthesis from glycerol and urea. Afterwards, the function of acidic and basic sites in each reaction path identified in this research was elucidated based on the reactant conversion and product selectivity. It proved that the acidic sites were inclined to promote the reaction towards GLC synthesis, while all the paths towards the by-products were significantly catalyzed by the basic sites. However, the catalysts with extra strong acidity did not facilitate the GLC production due to poisoning of surface active sites by urea adsorption. So, a well-balanced acidic-basic property was important to obtain high GLC yield with good selectivity. Among all the catalytic samples, the catalysts with Zr4+: (Al3+ + Zr4+) = 0.3 showed the best catalytic performance with 87.8% yield of GLC. Moreover, different reaction parameters such as reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst amount and vacuum degree were investigated and optimum conditions were established. Additionally, this catalyst could be readily recycled and reused for at least four times without any activation treatment, while still possessing high activity.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of Zr on the performance of Mg-Al catalysts via hydrotalcite-like precursors for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from urea and glycerol
